q: What is a relation between two sets?
a:
A relation ($R$) from set $A$ to set $B$ is a subset of their Cartesian product.
Formula: $R \subseteq A \times B$.
If $(a,b) \in R$, we write $aRb$.

q: What is a relation on a set?
a: A relation on a set $A$ is any subset of $A \times A$. Thus, both elements of each ordered pair belong to the same set $A$.
A relation $R$ on set $A$ is reflexive if $(a,a) \in R$ for all $a \in A$.
A relation $R$ on set $A$ is symmetric if $(a,b) \in R$ implies $(b,a) \in R$, for all $a,b \in A$.
A relation $R$ on set $A$ is transitive if $(a,b) \in R$ and $(b,c) \in R$ together imply $(a,c) \in R$, for all $a,b,c \in A$.

q: When is a relation called an equivalence relation?
a:
A relation $R$ is an equivalence relation if it is:
1. Reflexive
2. Symmetric
3. Transitive

q: What is the set of all equivalence classes of an equivalence relation?
a:
The set of all equivalence classes forms a partition of the set $A$.
This means every element of $A$ belongs to exactly one equivalence class.

A function ($f$) from set $A$ to set $B$ is a special relation where every element of $A$ has exactly one image in $B$.
Notation: $f: A \to B$.

q: What is the domain, co-domain, and range of a function?
a:
For $f: A \to B$:
• Domain: Set $A$.
• Co-domain: Set $B$.
• Range: The set of all images, $\{ f(x) : x \in A \} \subseteq B$.

A function $f: A \to B$ is one-one (Injective) if:
1. $f(x_1) = f(x_2) \Rightarrow x_1 = x_2$.
2. Each element of $B$ has at most one pre-image.

A function $f: A \to B$ is onto (Surjective) if for every $b \in B$, there exists at least one $a \in A$ such that $f(a) = b$.
This means Range($f$) = Co-domain.

A function is bijective if it is both one-one and onto.
A bijective function establishes a one-to-one correspondence between elements of $A$ and $B$.

If $f: A \to B$ and $g: B \to C$, the composition of $f$ and $g$ is $g \circ f: A \to C$.
Definition: \[(g \circ f)(x) = g(f(x))\] for all $x \in A$, provided Range($f$) $\subseteq$ Domain($g$).

A function $f: A \to B$ is invertible if there exists a function $g: B \to A$ (the inverse, $f^{-1}$) such that:
1. \(g(f(x)) = x, \; \forall x \in A\) (or $g \circ f = I_A$)
2. \(f(g(y)) = y, \; \forall y \in B\) (or $f \circ g = I_B$)

q: When does a function have an inverse?
a: A function $f: A \to B$ has an inverse if and only if it is bijective (one-one and onto).

q: State the property of inverse function composition.
a:
If $f$ is invertible, then:
\[f^{-1} \circ f = I_A \quad \text{and} \quad f \circ f^{-1} = I_B\] where $I_A$ and $I_B$ are identity functions on sets $A$ and $B$, respectively.

Let $f(x) = 3x + 2$.
To find $f^{-1}$, set $y = f(x)$ and solve for $x$:
\[y = 3x + 2 \Rightarrow x = \frac{y - 2}{3}\]Hence $f^{-1}(y) = \frac{y - 2}{3}$.
